title: LinkDaViz - Automatic Binding of Linked Data to Visualizations
segmentation: Hello everybody.
I'm Claudia Talmon working as a research assistant at the University of Bonn and as a software engineer at Fraunhofer.
I'm glad to present the approach we've been developing for visualizing link data.
Which.

With the goal of providing user friendly means for exploring link data by supporting users in finding suitable visualizations while hiding technical details of link data and visualization configurations.
Well, the challenge.
Of linked data visualization consistent finding.
A kind of balance between generality and usability of the approach.
Way too accomplish this.
We propose a largely automatic visualization workflow which guides the user step by step through the process of selecting data and configuring visualizations.
By automatically computing visualization recommendations.
The approach is based on.
Heuristic analysis of the structure of the input data.
For data categorization and a matching algorithm for binding data visualizations.
The binding between data and visualizations is modeled as an assignment problem.
Unsolved by the bit, but it graph matching algorithm introduced by Kuhn and Moncus.
OK.
The visualization workflow.
Start with the selection.
And exploration of our input data set.
From which the user selects the part of the data he is interested in visualizing.

The selected data serves together with the visualization metadata extracted from the visualization Ontology as an input from as input for the recommendation algorithm, which automatically computes this these bindings.
The suggested visualizations are then displayed to the user ready for selection and further customization.
OK, in order to facilitate the browsing and selection of data.
The input data set is represented as a list of trees as shown in the picture.
Each tree is undirected tree with root node with the root node corresponding to RDF class and is defined by a set of.
Nodes aren't a set of edges.
The set of notes consists of.
Internodes representing RDF object properties and leaf nodes representing RDF data properties.
Each data property has a scale for categorizing the input data and the role for excluding unreasonable mappings.
The scales are we are using are nominal for categorical data and interval and ratio for quantitative data.
Nominal data only has distinguished values and interval and ratio data.
Additionally, have undefined ordered between values and defined.
Numerical difference operator.
The difference between interval and ratio data is that ratio also also has an absolute zero point that allows for.
Adding values.
Based on this definitions, Stevens introduced hierarchy of scales, with nominal being the most generic and ratio.
The most specific scale.
The categorization of the input data is based.
On the data types of the data properties values and on the metadata extracted from the underlying RDF vocabularies.

Numerical data property.
It is categorized as.

Data property string.
It is categorized as nominal.

Roads.
That we assign to the data properties can be that of a domain or arrange.
Depending on the meta data we extract from the vocabularies, for instance.

If.
Name is RDF data Cube dimension property.
Or if we can extract this kind of information from the data set, then we categorize the property name as domain and if we can extract for population from the.
Data set that it is a measure property.
We categorize it as a range.
They mentioned properties and measure properties are.
RDF data cube vocabulary.
Specific terminologies.
Both scales and rolls are used in the computation of mappings to data to visualizations.
A visualization is represented by a set of parameters that define its structure and layout.
Structural parameters.
Describe the skeleton of a visualization.
An can be assembled.
Kind of visualization pattern.
For instance, the structural options of a column chart are horizontal.
And vertical axis and optional column groups.
These options we can assemble to.
A pattern similar to a function signature with domain patterns.
Parameters on the left and range parameters on the right.
Strict structural parameters have a set of scales.
Rolls.
And cardinality.
The set of scales represents the kind of input data that can be mapped to a certain parameter.
And the roles are used to restrict them.
Allow data properties either too.
Independent or dependent variables.
We need this to ensure that the data conforms to the structure of the visualization.
Enter cardinality indicates if a structure option is required or if it's optional or if it's single or multi valued.
For instance, the structural option horizontal and vertical axis.
Offer column charges are required.
Whereas the column groups are optional.
The mapping of the data properties to structural visualization paramaters.
Is modeled as an assignment problem.
Which is defined as follows.
Given a set of selected categorized data properties and a set of structural parameters of visualization.
Find a mapping.
With maximum number of assignments and minimal cost.
The weights are chosen in such a way that the lower the cost of a mapping, the higher the probability of finding a reasonable visualization configuration.
And a high number of assigned data properties ensures that a large part of the.
Data selected for visualization can be visualized.
For computing the costs.
We introduced.
Scales and rolls penalties.
Skate penalties express how well.
The.
Data, property scale and the structural visualization parameters scale.
Match.
A perfect match means.
That the scales are equal.
And an invalid message is given if.
A more generic data property scale is mapped to.
Specific parameter scale.

Because the data doesn't contain the information.

Doesn't make sense to map, for instance, if you have numbers.
At all.
Map numbers to.
But no.
Or vice versa if you.
If you map nominal data to ratio.

It's considered to be a valid mapping.
And we had a penalty for this.
Depending on on the information loss, for example.
If you map.
Raise your data scale to a nominal parameter.
Visualization, parametric scale.
Then the penalty will be higher than mapping interval.
Data scale to a nominal parameter scale because.
According to Stevens scale hierarchy, the.
Interval scale is more.
Is closer to the nominal, which is the most generic scale then?
The ratio scale, which would be the most specific one.
And the roll penalties are added if the role of data property.
Is unknown, but the parameter visualization parameter role is defined.
In order to.
Two prefer mappings with matching rules, because we would rather not map data properties with unknown roles to visualization parameters that require specific roles.
In case the data property roll is known, but.
Visualization parimeter role is undefined.
We also had a penalty rolls penalty.
In order to prefer mappings to parameters with defined roles.
Because we would rather map data properties with known roles to visualization parameters with defined roles, then to visualization parameters with undefined roles.
OK, based on these definitions.
Of scales, penalty mapping of data properties to visualization paramaters can be determined by summing up the scales penalty and the rolls penalty.
For each possible.
Match.
And choosing the set of matching matches that that have a minimal cost.
In this example, the population data property is assigned to the vertical axis.
And the name property is assigned to doors until access because the sum of the.
Yes, because the sum of the.
Scales and rolls penalty is zero, in contrast to the alternative assignment.
For instance, assigning population to horizontal axis and name two vertical axes are invalid because of technical, incompatible roles, and because the nominal.
Scale of the name property can be mapped to the ratio.
Scale of the vertical axis.
As a result, we obtain a column chart visualization that illustrates the population count of.
European countries.
OK.
In order to evaluate the level of difficulty for performing a visualization task, we performed a user study.
Where 20 participants took part.
Most of these participants experience little difficulties.
With the task tasks given and rated the.
Design of the visualization UI for for selecting the data and configuring visualizations as average to good.
And the overall level of satisfaction and quality of recommendation was rated positively by the users.
We also evaluated the effectiveness of the recommendation algorithm.
For this we selected 6 datasets from the web offering.
Sizes.
And measured.
The effectiveness by data coverage and information value of the produced visualizations.
Well, the data coverage expresses how many of the.
Selected properties where.
Meaningful mapped and information value of the visualization indicates how many of them.
Produced visualizations where reasonable.
But it should be noted that the quality.
Of the produced recommendations varied with the quality of the input data, and.
Of the number.
Of selected data properties.
OK, I think we're running out of time.
Well, um.
That would be it from my part.
Do you have any questions?
